title: How to recommend one should write his own biography - Quora

response.answer_text: First of all, I’d recommend approaching it as an autobiography, not a biography. It’s much, much more personal, and much, much more fun to read. Second, write it for you. You don’t have to be famous or rich to have led an interesting life — hell, you don’t even really need an interesting life to have an interesting life (if that makes sense). No matter how ordinary or mundane you think your life is, there’s still something worth writing about. Thirdly you’ll need to get comfortable with yourself, with the things that happened to you and the things that you did. You need to come to terms with your life and get comfortable talking about it. Last thing to consider before writing an autobiography is what you want to focus on. You will never be able to encompass an entire life in a book, nor should you want to. Most of life is repetitive, and only fun for the ones living it. I’m not going to write a book about how everyday after work I would relax and watch TV with my family because that’s not interesting. I’m going to write about my hardships, my obstacles and how I overcame them. Alright, considerations aside, here’s how to write an autobiography: Approach it as a memoir. It’s really intimidating to have to decide to write about ALL OF YOUR LIFE, ALL AT ONCE — so for that reason, decide one thing, one part of your life that you want to write about. You’ll be surprised at how many there are: how you fought your family’s poverty, your budding genius on the violin, your brother’s battle with OCD. They may all be interrelated (your brother developed his OCD to cope with poverty while you were driven to the violin to cope with his disorder while the violin lessons forced your family further into poverty), but you’ll find that choosing just one to focus on makes writing so much easier.Plan your story from start to finish. Really think about what events in your life are important to the story you want to tell. Birth, even though it’s technically the starting place, is usually a terrible place to begin. Choose something instead that’s really relevant to your story — for example, if you were to write about your violin skills, you might start with the first time you heard someone play the violin. Then you can map out the course of your life in terms of the violin, the first time you touched a violin, the first time you played it, each time you performed and how you changed between each.If you’re writing about your brother, maybe begin with some of the warning signs your family missed in the beginning. Trace the arc of his disorder from its origins to its peak to (if you’re lucky) his eventual recovery.Write everything. Describe absolutely everything you can in as precise detail possible. Remember everything you possibly can and dredge up memories you never knew you still had. Ceaselessly interrogate family and friends until everyone hates you. Write until you can’t possibly write anymore, then go back and add more.Go back and re-write. Focus on the important things of your story, cutting out all the rest. Maybe you should take out the part where you picked your nose in first grade and your brother made fun of you — but leave in the part where you watched him count the number of steps across the kitchen over and over for hours. It’s probably not necessary for the readers to know about the time you wore your shirt backwards to a violin lesson, but they will need to know about when your teacher told you that you have a real gift. Cut all the meaningless details and descriptions that don’t add to the story, so that you have a clear, concise narrative.Re-write again. This time, focus on you. It’s really easy, especially when writing about somebody else, to forget this is an autobiography, and your point of view is the most important point of view. If you’re writing about the violin, make sure it’s your journey — how you felt when you played that sonata, what your thoughts were when you preformed on stage. If you’re writing about your brother, be extra aware; this is your story, not his. How he felt is irrelevant; how it affected you is what matters.Keep editing and re-writing until you want to puke. Not much more to say here. Refine your story to perfection.(optional) Repeat steps 1 - 6 until you have stories on every aspect of your life. If you’re really determined to write an autobiography instead of a memoir, you’ll have to be ready for a challenge. Take all the stories you’ve written, and begin compiling them into one. Be scrupulous. Whatever you write can’t be twenty novels long, so you will have to cut out huge swaths of semi-essential information. Maybe even whole aspects of your life will be left out — do you really have room to write about your grandpa with dementia when you’re already up to the neck in violin music, OCD, and generations of poverty? It’s going to be rough, but keep going.I hope this helps

First of all, I don't recommend for no one will read it unless you are a famous person or in your life you went through remarkable experiences that can be of interest to others. Still, if you are adamant, I suggest you start with journal writing wher you put down all the important events you had and later go through it to make a cogent and interesting story of it with your word craft. If you are not that good at writing, and if you are filthy rich, you can hire a ghost writer and pay him to do the job and to keep his mouth shut about it and claim it to be your autobiography.
